description: You are a skilled hand-weaver in rural England, 1780. Most villagers farm or raise sheep, but you’ve built a reputation for fine linen and wool cloth. You own two looms in your cottage, employ three apprentices, and sell at the weekly market. Life is modest but stable — until whispers of ‘steam looms’ reach the village…
disruption: Steam-powered factories are opening in Manchester and Leeds…
question: Why are your customers suddenly buying cheaper cloth?
answers: A new fashion banned colorful cloth
Power looms produce fabric 20× faster than human hands
The king raised taxes on hand-made goods
fact: Between 1780 and 1810, British handloom weavers fell from ~250,000 to under 10,000.

description: You now run a successful gas-lamp manufacturing and street-lighting business in London. Your factory employs 180 workers producing lamps and mantles. Electric bulbs are still expensive toys for the rich — until Edison and Swan perfect them…
disruption: Electric lighting is sweeping cities overnight…
question: Why did cities stop buying your gas lamps?
answers: Electric bulbs are brighter, safer, and cheaper to run
Gas lamps were outlawed for being too beautiful
fact: By 1910, gas lighting jobs in the U.S. dropped 90%. Ice delivery collapsed with electric refrigerators.

description: Your family owns the largest livery stable, carriage works, and hay dealership in a growing Midwestern town. You shoe 200 horses a week and rent carriages to doctors and merchants — until Ford’s Model T rolls off the line…
disruption: Cars no longer eat hay or need horseshoes…
question: Why are your stables suddenly empty?
answers: A horse plague killed all animals
fact: U.S. horse population: 25 million (1915) → under 3 million (1960).

description: You run a chain of typing pools and secretarial colleges across the country. Businesses pay you to type documents and train typists — until IBM PCs and WordPerfect appear on every desk…
disruption: Everyone is buying their own computers…
question: Why did companies stop sending work to your typing pool?
answers: Word processors let anyone type and edit instantly
fact: Millions of dedicated typist jobs vanished in the 1980s–90s.

description: You own a successful accounting firm with 200 bookkeepers using ledgers and calculators…
question: Why are your clients doing their own spreadsheets?
answers: Excel automates weeks of work in minutes
fact: Manual bookkeeping jobs dropped ~70% in a decade.

description: You own a chain of travel agencies and the Yellow Pages advertising empire in your region…
disruption: People are booking flights on something called Expedia…
question: Why did foot traffic to your agency drop 80%?
answers: The internet lets anyone book online instantly

description: You own camera shops, GPS stores, and a chain of Blockbuster video rentals…
question: Why are people no longer buying your products?
answers: One device now replaces cameras, GPS, and video stores
fact: Blockbuster had 9,000 stores in 2004 → bankrupt by 2010.

description: You run a successful data-center and server-hosting company for enterprises…
disruption: Amazon Web Services is eating your lunch…
question: Why are companies shutting down their server rooms?
answers: Cloud makes servers instant and 90% cheaper
fact: On-premise server market shrank >60% in a decade.

description: You built a 500-person digital agency: designers, copywriters, React developers, and junior programmers…
disruption: ChatGPT, Midjourney, and Claude just went viral…
question: Why did 80% of your clients cancel contracts overnight?
answers: AI generates text, images, and code instantly
fact: By 2025, AI tools eliminated millions of routine creative and coding jobs.

description: You now run a successful AI agency with 60 brilliant prompt engineers and agent builders. Your clients are huge corporations — until fully autonomous AI companies appear…
disruption: AI agents now start and run entire companies without humans…
question: Why did your last human client just fire you?
answers: Autonomous AI corporations outcompete human-led firms
fact: Projections: by 2035, >50% of Fortune 500 may be AI-native with <10 human employees.

pivots.name: Nuclear micro-reactor leasing for AI data centers
